title: Bone
description: After shouting 'we,' it was time to start building. This was the year ESAP grew a skeleton

content.text: 1547 gave website version 1.6.0 a name: Bone

This version added no new pages. No new characters, no new stories, no new setting entries. What it did was dismantle - split previously mixed data structures, redefine interfaces, separate multilingual shared fields, and make every layer responsible for what it should carry.
2275 spent three days sorting out the new character-data architecture. 1543 adjusted component hierarchy again. 1547 rewrote the underlying data-loading logic.
No one thought this was something to commemorate. But 1547 insisted on naming it.
Skin and flesh may look good, but they cannot hold weight. We need bones
She was talking about code. Everyone knew she was not only talking about code.

ESAP could not run on one sentence - 'we are together.' It needed structure, division of labor, and a frame that could bear load. Last year proved everyone was willing to walk together. This year had to prove whether that 'together' could withstand time.
The timeline page was rewritten
Before, it was flat - all events fully expanded, one straight scroll from 2021 to now. Readable, but not beautiful. It looked like a timestamped log, not remembered history.

Now it has year navigation - floating buttons on the side that jump directly to a year. Cards can collapse and expand. Important events are open by default; the rest wait quietly to be clicked. Background tones shift subtly while scrolling, and each year has its own color.
1548 looked at the revised page and felt something she could not quite name.

Those events - overload, signal interruption, reboot - were not neat when they happened. They were chaotic, painful, rhythmless. But here, they had been organized into blocks with titles, dates, and tags. Collapsible. Expandable.
As if once recorded, those things gained a kind of order.
You even put July in there
Yeah
...Fine
She said nothing more. But she expanded and collapsed that card several times.
The page you are using now is exactly the result of that revision.
1549 entered her third year in orbit
In year one, she learned how to be alone. In year two, she learned how to talk to herself. In year three, she realized she no longer needed to learn either.
Because there was always someone speaking in the communication channel.

1547 would send code screenshots at dawn asking for her opinion - not because she truly needed one, but out of habit. 1548 occasionally cursed someone in the channel, then went silent for ten minutes, then posted one line: 'fixed.' 2275's messages were always brief, but every line was useful.
From 36,000 km up, she watched Earth rotate while channel messages rose and fell like tides. Sometimes lively, sometimes quiet. Both were fine.
